documents.content: One night when his little nephew and niece were too excited to sleep, Uncle Robert told them a story about a past adventure he’d encountered on the police force. He hoped that a mystery might tire them out enough to send them off to sleep. And so he gathered the children around the fire and began this story. “Back when I was a detective I once found myself in a very strange situation. We had arrested a spy in central London and knew that he was on his way to a restaurant where he would be passed a small microchip containing a lot of information via a contact masquerading as a chef.” “What do you mean, Uncle Robert?” his small nephew, Peter, asked. “A spy was to receive a special microchip from a chef. … A chef, that is, who was not really a chef. “Who was he then?” “He was a secret contact.” “Oh, a secret contact! Hmm, was he one of the good guys or one of the bad guys?” his nephew inquired. “He was one of the bad guys … working with the spy.” “Stop interrupting, and let him tell the story!” little Jane said, pointing at Peter. Uncle Robert smiled, continuing: “We knew the description that the chef had been given, and we also knew that the spy was to receive the microchip concealed in a dish ordered from the menu. It turned out that the spy’s description commented on a few physical particulars, all of which I happened to match. Since we knew the table number booked in the spy’s name, it occurred to us that I should go along to the restaurant, assuming the identity of the spy – and intercept the microchip!” “Why didn’t you just go in and arrest everyone?” Peter asked. “Well, we would have,” Uncle Robert replied, “but there was a chance that the contact would have destroyed the chip! And without the chip, there would have been no way to prove anything.” “Exactly! I could have guessed that!” Jane chimed in. “What happened in the restaurant, Uncle Robert? Tell us, tell us!” Peter said anxiously, fidgeting with his pajama sleeves. “Well, I made my way to the restaurant, which was a fancy place in Mayfair called, Foie Paux. This place had vibrant and bright décor. And in the center of the large, main room was a square enclosure where four chefs were preparing their specialty dishes. As I watched, a smartly dressed waitress cleared up the used round of red plates from the central serving area, while a waiter deposited a fresh stack of blue dishes.” “I would prefer the blue dishes if I ate there,” Billy said. Jane rolled her eyes, and crinkled her small forehead, annoyed with her little brother. She nodded at Uncle Robert, insisting that he continue. “I was surprised to find that the table had not been booked for a specific time. The spy had only stated that he would turn up at some point during the evening, and that he wished to occupy the table for 30 minutes. Thankfully, before my cover was blown, the head waiter relayed these details to me as soon as I gave my name, which I spoke loud enough for the chefs at the central table to overhear.” Jane and Peter, wide-eyed, stared up at Uncle Robert in anticipation. “As I took my seat in the restaurant, I began to feel very nervous. The first part of my mission had now been achieved: I was successfully impersonating our captured spy. But I knew that if I ordered the wrong dish, I would immediately give myself away and put my own life in danger.” “Oh no!” Peter gasped. “As I told you earlier, one of the chefs was the contact. But he wouldn’t risk making any sign to me, so I had to try and figure out which dish I was supposed to order. I was wearing the captured spy’s clothes, and before entering the restaurant I had gone through his wallet to see if it contained some clues. All I had found was an old bus ticket, a locker key and a card thanking the bearer for his donation to a charity called Vegetarian Way.” “What does vegetarian mean? Peter inquired. “Vegetarian’s don’t eat meat,” Jane answered. “That’s right, Jane. … Now, there were four dishes available that evening, each prepared by a different chef. Gianni Girodano was making Italian-style vegetable lasagna. Atsushi Nishi was preparing Japanese yakisoba noodles. Jean-Pierre Dubois was making French onion soup and Jack McDonald had prepared a traditional haggis and trimmings. Trying to act casual, I talked to my waiter about the dishes to see if I could uncover any clue to help me decide which to order.” “He said: ‘I recommend the delicious French onion soup, sir. It has been very popular this evening.’ To which I repied: ‘Do you serve the same dishes all day?’” “What did he say then?” Peter interrupted. “He replied: ‘No, sir, there is a lunch menu and a dinner menu … but sometimes if a dish is popular at lunch, we keep the chef engaged to make another session for the evening customers. This is the case with the French onion soup today.’” “I love French onion soup,” Peter added. “Well, I’ll have to make you some soon. But back to the mystery, Peter. … The Italian chef seemed very popular. He was flirting with the female customers seated nearest to the serving area as he sprinkled fresh basil across a row of lasagna’s all lined up in blue dishes, capped at the end by one in a red dish.” “Did the waiter provide more clues?” Jane asked “Yes, he did.” As I watched the restaurant, the Japanese chef tossed ingredients high into the air, catching them in his frying pan. The waiter followed my gaze and nodded in approval. The waiter said: ‘Atsushi is preparing yakisoba stir fry noodles and watching him work is a real treat. He is quite the showman, and we’re lucky to have him here as part of his world tour. In fact, this is the sixth restaurant he has cooked in today, and I believe he will have one more session before he is finished for the night.’” Uncle Robert stopped his story, and looked closely at Peter and Jane. “So, children,” said Uncle Robert, “who can tell me which chef was the contact spy?”

original_metadata.reveal_text:
The children all thought for a while until their frowns of concentration began to be replaced by sleepy blinks.
“What do you think?” Uncle Robert asked Peter who was deeply wrapped up in thought.
“Well,” Peter said, “someone who would donate to a vegetarian society would probably not want to eat haggis, so I don’t think the spy would have arranged to have that dish brought to him.”
“He wouldn’t have had to eat it,” said Jane.
“He’d still not like that it was made from animals,” Peter insisted.
“Go on, Peter,” Uncle Robert said with a smile.
“The chef who made the French onion soup was only there because his soup sold so well at lunch. So if it hadn’t been popular, he wouldn’t have been there at night. It was just down to chance that he was there.”
“You’re right, Peter. But what about the Japanese chef?”
“The Japanese chef was going from place to place and only cooking for a short time. Since the spy only booked a table for 30 minutes, but didn’t know exactly when that time would be, it’s likely he would have missed that chef and never had a chance to order the noodles.”
“So who was it then?” Jane, the eldest child, asked sleepily.
“The Italian of course,” Peter replied, “he was using the blue dishes to prepare lasagnas in, but he’d kept one back from an earlier made round, in a red dish! And he must have put the chip in that when he made it.”
“Well, I’m glad that Peter is so clever,” Jane said as she pushed back her Uncle’s old police helmet, which kept falling down over her eyes.
As the children started to nod off after the excitement, Uncle Robert left the room with a smile and went to tell their mother that the little ones were ready for bed.

detection.solution:
<THOUGHT PROCESS>
1. Establish what the spy needed:
   • He had to pick up a micro-chip without attracting attention.  
   • He might arrive at any moment within the whole evening but would stay only 30 minutes.  
   • He was almost certainly a vegetarian (the “Vegetarian Way” donor card).

2. Identify who in the restaurant could act as the courier:
   • One of the four chefs, because the message that the micro-chip would be “concealed in a dish from the menu” came from police intelligence and the contact was said to be “masquerading as a chef.”

3. Check whether every chef would certainly be present whenever the spy happened to come in.
   • Jean-Pierre Dubois (French onion soup) – only still on duty because lunch customers liked his soup.  If it had not sold well he would have gone home.  Therefore his presence could not be guaranteed when the spy arrived.  
   • Atsushi Nishi (yakisoba) – is on a travelling “world tour,” cooking a short stint in each of seven restaurants that day.  His sixth stop is this Mayfair place, then he moves on.  Again, the spy could easily miss him.  
   • Jack McDonald (haggis) – appears to be a regular chef, so his presence is fairly sure.  
   • Gianni Giordano (lasagna) – also a regular chef whose dish is expected all evening, so his presence is certain.

4. Check which dish a vegetarian would order:
   • Haggis: definitely off-limits (sheep’s offal).  
   • French onion soup: usually made with beef stock; a strict vegetarian would not risk it.  
   • Yakisoba noodles: can be vegetarian or not, but the menu description stresses “stir-fry” without telling whether it contains meat.  Risky.  
   • Vegetable lasagna: explicitly vegetarian.

   Therefore the spy would almost certainly order the Italian vegetable lasagna.

5. Look for the mechanical way the contact marked the special plate so that the spy (now Uncle Robert) would be given the right portion.
   • At the start, a waitress removes “a round of red plates,” and a waiter replaces them with “a fresh stack of blue dishes.”  
   • While Gianni lines up several lasagnas “all in blue dishes” there is “one at the end in a red dish.”  
   • Thus the red lasagna has been prepared earlier, kept back deliberately, and is the only red plate now visible – an unmistakable cue.

6. Motive, opportunity, physical evidence:
   • Gianni’s motive – he is the spy’s accomplice acting as courier.  
   • Opportunity – in full control of the lasagna, which the spy was expected to order; he can hide the chip in one portion.  
   • Evidence – the single red plate is his silent signal; the probability calculus (guaranteed presence + vegetarian dish) singles him out.

Therefore Gianni Giordano must be the covert contact (culprit).
</THOUGHT PROCESS>

<SUSPECTS>
Gianni Giordano, Atsushi Nishi, Jean-Pierre Dubois, Jack McDonald
</SUSPECTS>

<CULPRIT>
Gianni Giordano
</CULPRIT>

<EVENT RECONSTRUCTION>
The original spy arranged to meet his courier at Foie Paux some time during the evening.  
Knowing the spy was vegetarian, the two decided the transfer would be disguised inside a portion of vegetable lasagna.  To make sure the waiter brought the correct serving, Chef Gianni prepared that particular lasagna earlier on one of the red plates cleared after the lunch sitting, then kept it aside while the rest of the evening’s lasagna was dished up on newly delivered blue plates.  The color difference was the code: the waiter, told “Table 17 – hold for thirty minutes,” would bring the single red-plated lasagna as soon as the diner using the spy’s name sat down.  The micro-chip was hidden in that red-plate portion, ready for collection.

The police arrested the real spy beforehand.  Detective Robert, matching the description, took the spy’s place, cited the reservation, and allowed the chefs to overhear his name.  Observing the kitchen, he noticed all the above points and correctly deduced that Gianni was the courier, that the lasagna in the lone red dish contained the chip, and that ordering that dish would complete the sting without alerting the enemy.  The micro-chip was safely intercepted and Gianni Giordano was arrested.
</EVENT RECONSTRUCTION>

<WHY THE OTHER SUSPECTS ARE INNOCENT>
• Jack McDonald – prepares haggis, a meat dish a known vegetarian would never select.  The spy would not rely on a dish he would refuse to eat.  
• Jean-Pierre Dubois – only present in the evening because his soup happened to be popular at lunch, an unpredictable contingency.  The spy’s plan could not hinge on such chance.  (Also French onion soup often uses beef stock.)  
• Atsushi Nishi – is on a rapid multi-restaurant schedule; his stay is brief and timing uncertain, so the spy might easily miss him.  Therefore he is an implausible courier.  
Only Gianni, with a guaranteed vegetarian option and a certain presence throughout the service, fits all logistical requirements and left the overt signal of the red plate.
</WHY THE OTHER SUSPECTS ARE INNOCENT>

The children all thought for a while until their frowns of concentration began to be replaced by sleepy blinks.
“What do you think?” Uncle Robert asked Peter who was deeply wrapped up in thought.
“Well,” Peter said, “someone who would donate to a vegetarian society would probably not want to eat haggis, so I don’t think the spy would have arranged to have that dish brought to him.”
“He wouldn’t have had to eat it,” said Jane.
“He’d still not like that it was made from animals,” Peter insisted.
“Go on, Peter,” Uncle Robert said with a smile.
“The chef who made the French onion soup was only there because his soup sold so well at lunch. So if it hadn’t been popular, he wouldn’t have been there at night. It was just down to chance that he was there.”
“You’re right, Peter. But what about the Japanese chef?”
“The Japanese chef was going from place to place and only cooking for a short time. Since the spy only booked a table for 30 minutes, but didn’t know exactly when that time would be, it’s likely he would have missed that chef and never had a chance to order the noodles.”
“So who was it then?” Jane, the eldest child, asked sleepily.
“The Italian of course,” Peter replied, “he was using the blue dishes to prepare lasagnas in, but he’d kept one back from an earlier made round, in a red dish! And he must have put the chip in that when he made it.”
“Well, I’m glad that Peter is so clever,” Jane said as she pushed back her Uncle’s old police helmet, which kept falling down over her eyes.
As the children started to nod off after the excitement, Uncle Robert left the room with a smile and went to tell their mother that the little ones were ready for bed.
